V. 1, 2 venit enim mz'lzz' Pla- tonis in mentem, quem accepimus primum lzz'c dispulare solitum: cuius etiam illi propinqui hortuli non memoriam solum mihi afferunt, sed ipsum videntur in conspectu meo ponere. Hic speu- sippus, hic Xenocrates, lzz'c eins auditor Polemo: cuius illa ipsa sessio filit quam videmus. When Horace was at Athens the head of the Academic school was Theomnestm, whose lectures Brutus attended after the murder of Caesar (Plut. Brut. XXIV.). The expression however seems to be here a general one for the study of philosophy: Horace nowhere shows any special attachment to the Academic doctrines ε he professes himself rather a follower of Epicurus, though occasionally attracted to Stoic views of life and the universe.

Horace did not, like Pompeius Varus and other of his friends, join the forces of Sextus Pompeius and continue the struggle, but gave up arms at once.

50. inopem: Horace's father's estate had evidently been confiscated aster the victory of the triumvirs.
